en_first_half: From the corner of the divan of Persian saddle-bags on which he was lying, smoking, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton could just catch the gleam of the honey-sweet and honey-coloured blossoms of a laburnum, whose tremulous branches seemed hardly able to bear the burden of a beauty so flamelike as theirs; and now and then the fantastic shadows of birds in flight flitted across the long tussore-silk curtains that were stretched in front of the huge window, producing a kind
en_second_half: of momentary Japanese effect, and making him think of those pallid, jade-faced painters of Tokyo who, through the medium of an art that is necessarily immobile, seek to convey the sense of swiftness and motion. The sullen murmur of the bees shouldering their way through the long unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence round the dusty gilt horns of the straggling woodbine, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive. The dim roar of London was like the bourdon note of a distant organ.

en_results_raw: The effect of a fleeting, ethereal dance, as if the very essence of the natural world had been distilled onto the walls of the room. The scent of the laburnum wafted in, a heady perfume that mingled with the acrid smell of cigarette smoke, creating a pungent aroma that was both alluring and overpowering. Lord Henry's eyes, half-lidded as they were, seemed to gleam with a knowing light, as if he were savoring the beauty of the scene before him, and the languid, indulgent air that filled the room. The soft rustle of the curtains, the gentle creak of the wooden floorboards beneath his feet, and the distant hum of the city outside all blended together to create a sense of languor, a feeling of being suspended in a world of one's own, where time itself seemed to stand still. And yet, despite the air of languor, there was a sense of tension, a sense of anticipation, that hung in the air, like the promise of a storm about to break, or the whispered promise of a secret yet to be revealed.

Lord Henry, con la mirada perdida en la visión de la codesa, se sintió invadido por un sentimiento de paz y serenidad, como si la belleza de la naturaleza hubiera encontrado un refugio en la habitación, y él, en ese momento, fuera el dueño de todo lo que lo rodeaba. La música de un piano, que provenía de la habitación contigua, se filtraba suavemente en la habitación, creando un contrapunto perfecto con el susurro de las cortinas y el canto de los pájaros, y Lord Henry se sintió transportado a un mundo de ensueño, donde la realidad y la fantasía se fundían en una sola realidad. La belleza de la codesa, la música, las cortinas y el atardecer se unieron en un espectáculo que parecía haber sido creado especialmente para él, y Lord Henry se sintió agradecido por haber sido testigo de ese momento de perfección. Sin embargo, su paz fue interrumpida por el sonido de la puerta que se abría, y la entrada de una figura que parecía haber sido creada para perturbar la armonía de la habitación.

en_results: The delicate, intricately carved wooden frame seemed to glow with an otherworldly light, as if the very essence of the subject had been distilled into the brushstrokes of the artist's skilled hand.
en_results_raw: The delicate, intricately carved wooden frame seemed to glow with an otherworldly light, as if the very essence of the subject had been distilled into the brushstrokes of the artist's skilled hand. The young man's piercing blue eyes seemed to follow the viewer around the room, his chiseled features and strong jawline radiating an aura of quiet confidence and intelligence. A delicate lace collar adorned his neck, and a sprinkle of freckles across the bridge of his nose added a touch of whimsy to his otherwise stern expression. The artist's use of light and shadow created a sense of depth and dimension, drawing the viewer's eye inexorably to the subject's enigmatic smile, which seemed to hold a secret that only he knew. As the light danced across the canvas, the colors seemed to shift and change, imbuing the portrait with a sense of life and vitality that was nothing short of mesmerizing. The overall effect was one of breathtaking beauty, a true masterpiece that seemed to capture the very essence of the human spirit.

en_results_raw: themselves in a secluded arbor, where they could smoke and talk without being overheard. The night air was filled with the sweet scent of blooming flowers, and the sound of a nearby fountain created a soothing background melody. Lord Henry, with a mischievous glint in his eye, began to expound on the idea that true individuality was nothing more than a carefully crafted facade, a mask that one wore to conceal the emptiness within. He had always found the American approach to marriage to be refreshingly straightforward, if a bit too hasty for his taste, whereas the English tradition of engagement seemed to offer a more measured pace, a chance to savor the anticipation and uncertainty that came with the promise of a future union. Lord Henry, ever the provocateur, seemed to be goading him, pushing him to consider the implications of his own engagement to Sibyl Vane, a young actress whose beauty and talent had captivated him, but whose temperament and circumstances he was only just beginning to understand.

En este sentido, la idea de que la tecnología ha reemplazado a la humanidad en la creación de conexiones significativas es, en mi opinión, un mito que debemos desmentir. La verdadera conexión humana se forja en el calor de la conversación, en la risa, en la empatía y en la comprensión mutua, y no en la frialdad de una pantalla o una pantalla de teléfono. Por eso, creo que es hora de que volvamos a valorar la importancia de la comunicación cara a cara y de la interacción social en vivo, antes de que sea demasiado tarde.

en_first_half: “It is an interesting question,” said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the lad’s unconscious egotism, “an extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves,
en_second_half: and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.”

As he smoothed out the wrinkles, he couldn't help but think of the countless times he had seen it used to cover the bodies of the deceased, a symbol of respect and dignity in death. But this was no ordinary burial, and the coverlet seemed to mock him with its beauty and elegance. He tied the edges together with a delicate silver cord, the sound of the metal clicking into place a harsh reminder of the reality of what he was doing. The room seemed to grow darker, as if the shadows themselves were closing in around him, and Dorian felt a shiver run down his spine. He took a step back, his eyes fixed on the covered object, and wondered if he had made a terrible mistake. The silence was oppressive, and he felt the weight of his secret bearing down on him. He knew he had to get out of there, to leave the room and the thing behind, but his feet seemed rooted to the spot. The coverlet seemed to be watching him, its gold embroidery glinting with an otherworldly light, and Dorian felt a sense of foreboding wash over him. He knew he had to act quickly, before he lost his nerve, and with a sense of determination, he turned and made his way towards the door, the sound of his footsteps echoing through the room like a death knell.

He felt that he had lived in every age of the world, and that he had been to every land; that he had lain with every lover, and fought at every battle, and feasted with every king, and been the friend of every great man, and the lover of every beautiful woman. His imagination was a kaleidoscope of memories, a vast and intricate tapestry of experiences, woven from the threads of his own desires and the dreams of others. And yet, despite the boundless scope of his imagination, he was acutely aware of the limitations of his own life, the narrow and circumscribed existence that he had lived, the dull and grey reality that lay behind the shimmering veil of his fantasies. He felt that he was living two lives, one of them a dull and prosaic reality, the other a vibrant and colourful dream, and that the two were inextricably intertwined, each one influencing the other, and yet remaining forever separate and distinct. A menudo se preguntaba si los personajes de las novelas eran más auténticos que él mismo, si sus experiencias y emociones eran más verdaderas que las de los héroes y heroínas de las historias que leía. La duda lo consumía, y se sentía atraído por la idea de que la literatura podía ser una forma de escapar de la realidad, de dejar atrás la vida que había elegido y sumergirse en un mundo de ficción donde podía ser alguien más. Pero también sabía que la literatura era una forma de conexión con la humanidad, una forma de comprenderse a sí mismo y a los demás, y que en sus páginas encontraba una verdad que lo hacía reflexionar sobre su propia existencia. La ambigüedad de su relación con la literatura lo llevó a preguntarse si era un artista o un espectador, si era el creador de su propia historia o simplemente un personaje más en el gran drama de la vida. La incertidumbre lo acompañó durante mucho tiempo, pero finalmente llegó a la conclusión de que la literatura era una parte integral de sí mismo, una forma de expresar su alma y de conectarse con la humanidad. Y en ese momento, se sintió libre, libre de elegir su propio camino y de crear su propia historia, libre de ser quien quería ser. en_results_raw: The beauty of art and the transience of youth. His name was Lord Henry Wotton, and his words struck a chord within me, awakening a sense of curiosity and desire that I had never felt before. As I listened to his words, I felt a sense of liberation, as if the constraints of my upbringing and the expectations of society were being lifted, and I was free to explore the depths of my own desires. Lord Henry's words were like a key that unlocked a door, and I stepped through it, eager to discover the secrets that lay beyond. From that moment on, I was forever changed, my perception of the world and myself altered by the encounter with the charismatic and enigmatic Lord Henry. His influence seeped into my very being, and I found myself becoming increasingly obsessed with the idea of beauty and the pursuit of pleasure, no matter the cost. As the years passed, I became more and more enthralled by the concept of eternal youth and the beauty that it represented, and I began to make choices that would ultimately lead me down a path of destruction and despair. But at the time, I was blinded by the allure of Lord Henry's words, and I saw only the promise of a life of unbridled pleasure and freedom.

es_results: resultó ser un joven llamado Basil Hallward, un pintor que se enamoró de mi belleza y decidió capturarme en un lienzo. Me sentí halagado por su interés, pero también un poco incómodo, ya que no estaba acostumbrado a ser objeto de admiración. Sin embargo,
es_results_raw: resultó ser un joven llamado Basil Hallward, un pintor que se enamoró de mi belleza y decidió capturarme en un lienzo. Me sentí halagado por su interés, pero también un poco incómodo, ya que no estaba acostumbrado a ser objeto de admiración. Sin embargo, Basil me enseñó a apreciar mi belleza y a verla como una forma de arte, y pronto me convertí en su modelo favorito. Durante meses, posé para él, y con cada pincelada, sentí que mi belleza se volvía más real y más tangible. Pero, al mismo tiempo, sentí que algo dentro de mí comenzaba a cambiar, algo que no podía explicar. Mi vanidad crecía con cada día, y mi deseo de ser inmortal se volvía más intenso. Y fue en ese momento cuando Basil me presentó a alguien que cambiaría mi vida para siempre: a Lord Henry Wotton, un hombre que me enseñó a vivir para el placer y a rechazar las convenciones sociales. Su filosofía me atraía, y pronto me convertí en su discípulo, aprendiendo a ver el mundo de una manera diferente. Pero, al mismo tiempo, sentí que mi relación con Basil se volvía más tensa, ya que él no podía entender por qué me había vuelto tan diferente. Y fue en ese momento cuando sucedió algo que cambiaría mi vida para siempre: mi retrato, el que había sido pintado por Basil, comenzó a cambiar, reflejando la verdadera naturaleza de mi alma. Su belleza se volvió más radiante, pero también más oscura, reflejando la corrupción y la decadencia que se estaba apoderando de mí. Y fue en ese momento que supe que mi vida nunca sería la misma de nuevo.

The servant, a quiet, unobtrusive man, set the tray down on the bedside table and stood for a moment, watching his master with a look of concern etched on his face. He had been with Dorian for many years, and he knew that his master's sleep was not a natural one, but rather a desperate attempt to escape the turmoil that had been brewing inside him for weeks. The servant's eyes lingered on Dorian's face, taking in the lines of strain and the faint smudges of fatigue under his eyes, and he felt a pang of sympathy for the young man. He knew that Dorian was struggling with something, but he didn't know what, and he didn't dare to ask. Dorian's anxiety reached a boiling point as he paced back and forth in front of the fireplace, his eyes fixed on the door. He had been waiting for what felt like an eternity for Lord Henry Wotton to arrive, and the anticipation was almost unbearable. The sound of the doorbell echoed through the hallway, and Dorian's heart skipped a beat as he made his way to answer it, his hands trembling slightly as he grasped the handle and pulled the door open, revealing a tall, slender figure standing in the entrance, a charming smile spreading across his face as he greeted Dorian with a warm, "Good evening, my dear fellow." Dorian's anxiety began to dissipate as he stepped aside to let Lord Henry in, and the two men exchanged a warm handshake, the tension in the air dissipating as they entered the drawing room, where a fire crackled in the hearth, casting a warm glow over the room, and the sound of soft music drifted through the air, setting the tone for a night of conversation and revelry.

en_results_raw: The cold draft from the fireplace seemed to intensify his shivers, and he rubbed his hands together in an attempt to warm them up. La anfitriona se apresuró a cambiar de tema, intentando restablecer la atmósfera de cordialidad y amabilidad que había caracterizado la velada hasta ese momento. —¿Y qué hay de la música?— preguntó, dirigiéndose a un joven que estaba sentado en un rincón de la habitación, con un violín en la mano. —¿No es hora de que nos deleiten con una pieza?—. El joven sonrió, levantándose de su asiento, y comenzó a ajustar su instrumento, mientras la anfitriona se sentaba en su silla, con una sonrisa expectante en su rostro. La habitación se llenó de un silencio expectante, mientras el joven comenzaba a tocar una melodía suave y melancólica, que parecía transportar a todos los presentes a un mundo de ensueño y fantasía. La música era tan hermosa que parecía que el tiempo se había detenido, y solo existía el momento presente, lleno de belleza y armonía. La anfitriona cerró los ojos, permitiendo que la música la llevara a un lugar lejano, donde solo existía la paz y la serenidad. Pero, justo cuando la música parecía alcanzar su punto culminante, un ruido fuerte y repentino interrumpió la magia del momento, y la anfitriona abrió los ojos, sorprendida y confundida. —¿Qué ha pasado?— preguntó, mirando a su alrededor, intentando entender qué había causado el ruido. La habitación se llenó de murmullos y comentarios, mientras los invitados se miraban entre sí, intentando averiguar qué había sucedido. La anfitriona se levantó de su silla, preocupada, y se dirigió hacia la puerta, para ver qué había causado el ruido. Pero, justo cuando estaba a punto de salir, se detuvo en seco, con una expresión de sorpresa en su rostro. —¿Qué es esto?— preguntó, mirando a alguien que se encontraba en la puerta, con una sonrisa en su rostro. La habitación se llenó de un silencio absoluto, mientras todos los presentes se miraban a la persona que había entrado en la habitación, con una mezcla de sorpresa y curiosidad. La anfitriona se dirigió hacia la persona, con una expresión de sorpresa y confusión, y preguntó—: ¿Qué haces aquí?—. La persona sonrió, y respondió—: He venido a unirme a la fiesta, por supuesto. La anfitriona se detuvo, con una expresión de sorpresa en su rostro, y preguntó—: ¿Pero, ¿cómo has llegado aquí? La persona se encogió de hombros, y respondió—: He tomado un atajo, supongo. La anfitriona se miró a su alrededor, intentando entender qué había sucedido, y preguntó—: ¿Qué atajo? La persona sonrió, y respondió—: El atajo de la imaginación, por supuesto. La habitación se llenó de murmullos y comentarios, mientras los invitados se miraban entre sí, intentando entender qué había sucedido. en_results: The scent of damp earth and decaying leaves filled his senses as they walked through the dense forest, the trees towering above them like sentinels guarding a secret world. The beaters' cries grew
en_results_raw: The scent of damp earth and decaying leaves filled his senses as they walked through the dense forest, the trees towering above them like sentinels guarding a secret world. The beaters' cries grew louder, and Dorian quickened his pace, his heart pounding in anticipation of the hunt. The rustle of leaves beneath their feet was the only sound that broke the silence, and he felt a thrill of excitement as they approached the clearing where the great beast was said to reside. The trees parted, and a shaft of sunlight illuminated the glade, casting an otherworldly glow over the scene. In the center of the clearing stood an ancient, gnarled tree, its branches twisted and tangled in a way that seemed almost... unnatural. Dorian's guide, a grizzled old hunter with a face like weathered leather, nodded towards the tree, his eyes gleaming with a mixture of excitement and trepidation. "This is it," he whispered, his voice barely audible over the sound of the beaters. "This is where the beast is said to make its lair." Dorian's eyes locked onto the tree, his mind racing with the possibilities. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he gazed upon the twisted, ancient form, and he knew that he was on the cusp of something momentous, something that would change him forever.

It is in the metropolis that we have to record our triumphs and defeats, and learn to practice virtues with the same delicacy that we practice vices. The country is a place for simple tastes, it is true, but the world is a complicated web of desires and passions, and it is only in the city that we are forced to confront the darker aspects of our nature. It is there that we must learn to navigate the intricate dance of social etiquette, to balance our desires with our duties, and to cultivate the art of being both refined and ruthless. And it is precisely this delicate balance that makes the city so fascinating, so alluring, and so corrupting. The city is a place where one's character is constantly being tested, where one's values are constantly being challenged, and where one's very soul is constantly being tempted. It is a place where the strong are made stronger, and the weak are made weaker. And it is precisely this that makes the city so essential to the human experience, for it is there that we are forced to confront the very essence of our existence.
